<p><strong>Asia is primed for rapid healthcare change,</strong> driven by shifting demographics, rising consumer expectations, technological innovations, and limited legacy health infrastructure. Collectively, these factors could enable governments, payers, providers, and consumers to reimagine healthcare delivery and management. In response to these trends, consumer-centric digital health ecosystems are forming across Asia at unprecedented speed and scale. Today, digital health impacts more than a billion lives, and estimates show that digital health in Asia could collectively create up to $100 billion in value by 2025, up from $37 billion in 2020 (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20healthcare%20in%20asia%20digital%20health%20ecosystems/svg_dighealthecosys_exhibit1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Consumer-centric digital health value pools in Asia are expected to grow by 22 percent per annum through 2025." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20healthcare%20in%20asia%20digital%20health%20ecosystems/svg_dighealthecosys_exhibit1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>This article explores the driving factors for the emergence of health ecosystems in Asia, describes several emerging health ecosystem players, and defines strategic questions that potential ecosystem orchestrators should address.</p>
<h2>Healthcare disruption in Asia is increasingly likely</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Healthcare in Asia sits at the nexus of five fundamental forces driving transformation. These forces are not unique to Asia, nor do they impact each country and region within Asia to the same degree. Collectively, however, they exert a powerful drive to deliver healthcare in increasingly scalable, sustainable, and personalized ways.</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Aging population:</em> By 2025, Asia will be home to 456 million seniors age 65 or older, representing 10 percent of its population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="30ce59e2-f16a-425f-82c8-edab49972a7b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="30ce59e2-f16a-425f-82c8-edab49972a7b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">1 “The future of population in Asia: Asia’s aging population,” Asia Society, November 2010, sites.asiasociety.org.</span></span></span></a></span> This is a 14 percent growth over 2021—a rapid demographic change that both increases potential demand for health services and decreases the available supply of manpower to deliver care.</li>
    <li><em>Supply constraints:</em> With the exception of three countries in the region, the average number of doctors per 1,000 people in Asia is lower than the OECD average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2370a485-3027-481a-9663-455bc953a4bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2370a485-3027-481a-9663-455bc953a4bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See “Doctors and nurses,” in <em>OECD/WHO, Health at a Glance: Asia/Pacific 2020: Measuring Progress Towards Universal Health Coverage</em>, Paris: OECD Publishing, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, the World Health Organization has estimated a global shortfall of nine million nurses, with some of the worst affected countries located in Asia.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c88ec41a-a398-4f0a-abb0-370cd8bd0c71"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c88ec41a-a398-4f0a-abb0-370cd8bd0c71" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Nurse leaders in Asia identify key issues for State of the World’s Nursing report,” International Council of Nurses, December 2019, icn.ch.</span></span></span></a></span> While investments in hospitals and physician health infrastructure will continue to rise, traditional, labor-intensive care delivery models are unlikely to meet Asia’s rising health needs.</li>
    <li><em>Rising consumer expectations:</em> Consumers are spending more on health and wellness and increasingly demand access to convenient, affordable care. Furthermore, our consumer research has indicated that consumers are trading up in health and safety, with consumers in China, for example, willing to spend more on health-branded products during the pandemic. According to <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/feeling-good-the-future-of-the-1-5-trillion-wellness-market">McKinsey research</a>, 43.5 percent of Chinese consumers are reportedly spending more on their health in the past 12 months and 23.1 percent are spending more on their nutrition.</li>
    <li><em>Growing financial burden:</em> Today, governments in Asia, on average, spend only 4.5 percent of GDP on healthcare, compared with the OECD average of 12 percent. Yet governments are the dominant payer in Asia, accounting for 64 percent of all health expenditures in 2018 (compared with private insurers, which covered 7 percent). Finding ways to control the growth of healthcare expenditures remains an urgent public priority even while prioritizing quality and access for patients.</li>
    <li><em>Technological innovation:</em> Asia is home to half the world’s internet users, and already leads digital innovation worldwide in multiple sectors.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="32845bda-edc1-4a9f-854d-b7d14d554a5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="32845bda-edc1-4a9f-854d-b7d14d554a5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Oliver Tonby, Jonathan Woetzel, Wonsik Choi, Jeongmin Seong, and Patti Wang, “<a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/asias-future-is-now">Asia’s future is now</a>,” July 14, 2019, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Indeed, venture capital and private equity investments in digital health in Asia have grown at 38 percent CAGR from 2015 to 2020. As a result, as of 2020, Asia comprises 44 percent of global venture capital/private equity investments in digital health—$6 billion of $14 billion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<h2>The rise of health ecosystems in Asia</h2>
<p>Consumer-centric digital ecosystems are emerging across the world in response to these fundamental forces disrupting healthcare.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="262e1d89-71ef-4c40-98ef-476a7326cb14"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="262e1d89-71ef-4c40-98ef-476a7326cb14" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more on the next wave of healthcare innovation, see Shubham Singhal, Basel Kayyali, Rob Levin, and Zachary Greenberg, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-healthcare-innovation-the-evolution-of-ecosystems">The next wave of healthcare innovation: The evolution of ecosystems</a>, June 23, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Such ecosystems are designed to seamlessly deliver the right care in the right setting at the right time by integrating three critical components: (a) a network of health-service providers across care settings, (b) a system of intelligence that leverages behavioral, social, and health data to analyze patients’ needs and selects the appropriate provider, and (c) a technology backbone that enables data and insights to flow between care providers.</p>
<p>Importantly, health ecosystems are <em>enabled</em> by digital but are not <em>purely</em> digital, as they integrate both digital and physical health services. In addition, the breadth and complexity of health ecosystems means they cannot be encapsulated by a single entity, but typically consist of a central orchestrator anchored around a few self-built business models. They also manage multiple partners, including brick-and-mortar providers, healthtech start-ups, and IT vendors, to cover a more complete part of the care continuum.</p>
<p>As we discussed in “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-healthcare-innovation-the-evolution-of-ecosystems">The next wave of healthcare innovation: The evolution of ecosystems</a>,” “healthcare ecosystems of the future will likely be defined by the needs of different patient populations and their associated effective care journeys (including beyond care itself). The consumer-oriented nature of these ecosystems also will increase the number of healthcare touchpoints, with the goal of modifying patient behavior and improving outcomes.” Across Asia, a wide spectrum of players are beginning to define their approach to health ecosystems—not only healthcare incumbents such as insurers, providers, and governments but also nontraditional entrants such as consumer-technology giants, banks, telco-companies, industrial and retail conglomerates, and others. Emerging health ecosystems already impact more than a billion lives across Asia today (Exhibit 2), with prominent examples emerging in China, India, and Indonesia, among other markets.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20healthcare%20in%20asia%20digital%20health%20ecosystems/svg_dighealthecosys_exhibit2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Emerging health ecosystems already impact more than one billion lives in Asia." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20healthcare%20in%20asia%20digital%20health%20ecosystems/svg_dighealthecosys_exhibit2-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Four archetypes of health ecosystems are now emerging with different anchor use cases:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Broadening access to primary care:</em> Many of the largest health ecosystem players in Asia have rapidly grown by combining telemedicine and e-pharmacy services to address underserved populations. In China, for example, Ping An Good Doctor’s initial value proposition was allowing users to see a doctor online in minutes rather than waiting in line at a hospital for hours. Patients who required an in-person follow-up could subsequently get an expedited appointment booking at a hospital. Ping An Good Doctor then expanded into e-commerce transactions, providing consumer health products, generics, and health checkup kits on its platform.<br>
    <br>
    By contrast, AliHealth began with an e-pharmacy proposition in 2011, managing drug sales on Alibaba’s Tmall e-commerce platform and then expanding to home delivery of medications, provider partnerships for teleconsultations, appointment booking, and e-payments. Likewise in India, Practo launched as one of the first platforms to connect hospital-based physicians to patients across the country via video- and phone-based consultations, then expanded into medicine delivery, electronic health records management for hospitals, and even medical insurance services. Finally, in Indonesia, Halodoc has emerged as one of the largest platforms for patients to easily access general practitioner teleconsults, pharmacy delivery, and home lab services across more than 50 cities, addressing the lack of easy access to primary care outside of major hubs such as Jakarta and Surabaya.</li>
    <li><em>Improving health and wellness:</em> Some public and private payers have begun leveraging digital technologies to nudge consumers to monitor their health and lower the long-term cost of care. For example, since 2015 the Health Promotion Board (HPB) of Singapore has run the Healthy 365 program, which gamifies wellness by awarding redeemable Healthpoints based on daily step counts, healthy food purchases, health screenings, and more.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ba06cec-beac-471f-9fcb-e268221c26bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ba06cec-beac-471f-9fcb-e268221c26bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kevin Kwang, “HPB partners Fitbit to encourage Singaporeans to adopt healthier habits,” CNA, August 21, 2019, channelnewsasia.com.</span></span></span></a></span> In 2020, HPB expanded its program by partnering with Apple to launch LumiHealth, which layers in additional activity and wellness challenges for users of the Apple Watch.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7befd4e7-11fe-4686-8d28-e54601496710"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7befd4e7-11fe-4686-8d28-e54601496710" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ilyas Sholihyn, “Get fit and earn vouchers with LumiHealth, Singapore’s health initiative built Vitality<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1cf0dc5a-443b-4588-8d4b-13fa338609bd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1cf0dc5a-443b-4588-8d4b-13fa338609bd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“AIA Vitality,” AIA Group Limited, viewed July 2021, aia.com.</span></span></span></a></span> and Pulse by Prudential,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fd94a927-62e5-4531-a82a-03498d3c69e6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fd94a927-62e5-4531-a82a-03498d3c69e6" prudential.com.my.</span></span></span></a></span> respectively) to actively engage policyholders and guide them to the appropriate health provider.</li>
    <li><em>Expediting access to acute care:</em> An increasing number of hospitals are looking to establish digital “front doors” to engage with patients before and after their visit. Singapore has taken this model across its public healthcare system, with its HealthHub application serving as a single comprehensive digital entry point for all citizens to book appointments, order medications, and access vaccination records, disease risk assessments, and other health content. In addition, this model has scaled intensively in China, with close to 1,000 such “internet hospitals” established by early 2021 and detailed guidelines on social insurance reimbursement of online activities published by more than 20 cities. Approximately 70 percent of the internet hospitals are established by brick-and-mortar hospitals, such as Peking Union Medical College (PUMC) Hospital in Beijing and Huashan Hospital in Shanghai, and the remainder are led by digital consumer giants, such as Alibaba, Tencent, and Ping An.</li>
    <li><em>Managing and monitoring disease:</em> Following the success of Livongo and Omada in the United States, interest in digital chronic disease management platforms has increased across Asia. Among the largest examples are Medlinker and ClouDr in China, both of which have focused on building platforms to connect patients, physicians, payers, providers, and pharmacies. In fact, Medlinker has collaborated with 50,000 physicians and built patient-management tools to address diabetes, hepatic disease, and kidney disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="12241322-2b43-4033-a3ba-44b51f21f9a3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="12241322-2b43-4033-a3ba-44b51f21f9a3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“China’s leading chronic disease management platform,” Medical Federation, viewed July 2021, medlinker.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Medlinker also offers e-pharmacy services in collaboration with pharmaceutical companies. Meanwhile, ClouDr has taken a slightly different approach, establishing closer ties to hospitals by building a software-as-a-service platform for disease management<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1520116a-7d21-4ad8-a316-841b39666c5e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1520116a-7d21-4ad8-a316-841b39666c5e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Online health-care platform ClouDr mulls $500 million IPO,” Bloomberg News, May 27, 2021, bloomberg.com.</span></span></span></a></span> and providing prescriptions to patients who can collect drugs at offline pharmacy chains.</li>
</ul>
<p>To date, the markets have rewarded emerging health ecosystem innovators. As of March 2021, Tencent’s WeDoctor is estimated to be valued at up to $6.8 billion, which is 24 times the price-to-revenue ratio,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9e5088bb-d172-47c0-aaaf-b6f8ed52ea1c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9e5088bb-d172-47c0-aaaf-b6f8ed52ea1c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bloomberg, “Tencent-backed WeDoctor’s Hong Kong IPO looms with valuation near US$7b,” <em>The Business Times</em>, February 25, 2021, businesstimes.com.sg.</span></span></span></a></span> well in line with Ping An Good Doctor’s ratio of 16 times price-to-revenue, and significantly above the average price-to-revenue ratio of brick-and-mortar health providers in Asia, which is around tenfold. Even companies with smaller but rapidly scaling health ecosystems have seen valuation boosts supported in part by health ecosystem approaches. For example, Apollo Hospitals, one of the largest hospitals in India, launched its Apollo 24/7 health ecosystem in February 2020 to provide teleconsultations and home delivery of medicines. It announced strong results for the second half of FY 2021 in June.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b2375358-68cf-42d8-a12b-0b62b1369b1f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b2375358-68cf-42d8-a12b-0b62b1369b1f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rishabh Bhatnagar, “Apollo Hospitals’ stock hits a record high as analysts up targets after Q4,” BloombergQuint, June 25, 2021, bloombergquint.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>On the other hand, there are lessons that orchestrators need to draw to capture opportunities from the promising fundamentals and trends. First, building a successful ecosystem relies on aligning interests and connecting multiple stakeholders (for example, government, payer, provider, physician, and patients) within health systems, and in-depth analysis about the pain points of each party (down to the operational level) is key to reveal the opportunities. Second, a digital ecosystem does not imply a pure online approach and a successful model would require integration of both online and offline resources to build the care continuum and achieve the best outcomes. Third, the design of each business model will require definition of at least three functions, that is, flow generation, transaction conversion, and profit creation, to ensure a sustainable development.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="The next wave of healthcare innovation: The evolution of ecosystems" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/the%20next%20wave%20of%20healthcare%20innovation/standard-digital-health-ecosystems-96502236.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>The next wave of healthcare innovation: The evolution of ecosystems</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-healthcare-innovation-the-evolution-of-ecosystems" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Key questions to ask when building digital health ecosystems</h2>
<p>Despite the impressive impact numbers achieved to date by several health ecosystem players, we believe significant opportunity remains to expand the scope and breadth of health ecosystems across Asia. Speed is critical to capturing value in this nascent market, as the winner-take-all dynamics of ecosystem-based markets heavily favor first movers or fast followers. Thus, potential health ecosystem orchestrators should ask themselves the following four key questions:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>What is the source of advantage?</em> Successful ecosystem players typically start with a control point in mind. Consumer technology giants, such as Tencent with WeChat or Alibaba with Tmall, leverage their existing consumer platforms as an entry point upon which to offer health-related services. Payers, such as Ping An, AIA, and Prudential, leverage their large-scale distribution networks and access to patients’ claims data to shape service offerings. Finally, providers, such as Apollo, leverage their access to physicians and trusted reputation in health.</li>
    <li><em>What strategic capabilities and partnerships should be developed?</em> Being able to rapidly strike partnerships is a critical strategic muscle for ecosystem orchestrators expand services beyond their initial capabilities. For example, Halodoc partners with GoJek to leverage GoJek’s broad transportation network for home delivery of medications across Indonesia—a service that would be cost-prohibitive for the company to develop on its own. Tencent partners with pharma or medtech companies to develop AI-based diagnostics, or invests directly in healthtech start-ups.</li>
    <li><em>What is the time horizon and risk appetite to invest?</em> Given the complexity of healthcare, health ecosystems require significant investment over a long time horizon to successfully create their partnership network and user base. Ping An Good Doctor, for example, grew revenues by 35.5 percent from 2019 to 2020 but still recorded an adjusted net loss in 2020 of $80 million, six years after founding. Ping An, however, notes that 15 percent to 20 percent of new financial customers for their main businesses are sourced from their healthcare ecosystem each year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e3839ed8-b2e8-4744-8ac6-ba63722da33e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e3839ed8-b2e8-4744-8ac6-ba63722da33e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“2020 annual results,” Ping An, February 2021, group.pingan.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Indeed, rather than seeking to turn an immediate profit, companies seeking to develop health ecosystems should look at growth metrics or core business synergies as leading indicators of platform success.</li>
    <li><em>How will stakeholders interface with government healthcare priorities and regulators?</em> COVID-19 has led some local health governments to pilot online care delivery and virtual health, while still evaluating any fallout related to compliance, data security, and privacy. Working closely with local governments to develop digital health solutions could accelerate adoption and value capture.</li>
</ol>
<p>We believe that digital health ecosystems represent the future of healthcare in Asia and beyond. Both healthcare incumbents and new entrants will need to define what their future roles will be in orchestrating or participating in health ecosystems. Answering these four questions can help ecosystem orchestrators assess how they will realize the value at stake associated with building a digital health ecosystem, and thereby impact patients’ lives across Asia.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Axel Baur</strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey’s Hong Kong office and leads the healthcare practice for Asia, while <strong>Hann Yew</strong> is an associate partner in McKinsey’s Singapore office. <strong>Mengwei Xin</strong> is an associate partner in McKinsey’s Shanghai office.</p>
<p>The authors would like to thank Jovan Savicevic and Elisa Chen for their contributions to this article. </p>
<p>This article was edited by Elizabeth Newman, an executive editor in the Chicago office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The future of healthcare in Asia Digital health ecosystems","displayName":"The future of healthcare in Asia Digital health ecosystems","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"dcad8416-07ce-4e3d-acdf-78e9691fab7d","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":3,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The future of healthcare in Asia: Digital health ecosystems"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"The future of healthcare in Asia"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Asia is paving the way for digital health ecosystems, and potential ecosystem orchestrators can generate value by taking bold, strategic actions."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Asia is paving the way for digital health ecosystems, and potential ecosystem orchestrators can generate value by taking bold, strategic actions."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-07-21T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAsia is primed for rapid healthcare change,\u003c/strong\u003e driven by shifting demographics, rising consumer expectations, technological innovations, and limited legacy health infrastructure. Collectively, these factors could enable governments, payers, providers, and consumers to reimagine healthcare delivery and management. In response to these trends, consumer-centric digital health ecosystems are forming across Asia at unprecedented speed and scale. Today, digital health impacts more than a billion lives, and estimates show that digital health in Asia could collectively create up to $100 billion in value by 2025, up from $37 billion in 2020 (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis article explores the driving factors for the emergence of health ecosystems in Asia, describes several emerging health ecosystem players, and defines strategic questions that potential ecosystem orchestrators should address.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHealthcare disruption in Asia is increasingly likely\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eHealthcare in Asia sits at the nexus of five fundamental forces driving transformation. These forces are not unique to Asia, nor do they impact each country and region within Asia to the same degree. Collectively, however, they exert a powerful drive to deliver healthcare in increasingly scalable, sustainable, and personalized ways.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAging population:\u003c/em\u003e By 2025, Asia will be home to 456 million seniors age 65 or older, representing 10 percent of its population.[[footnote 1]] This is a 14 percent growth over 2021\u0026mdash;a rapid demographic change that both increases potential demand for health services and decreases the available supply of manpower to deliver care.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSupply constraints:\u003c/em\u003e With the exception of three countries in the region, the average number of doctors per 1,000 people in Asia is lower than the OECD average.[[footnote 2]] In addition, the World Health Organization has estimated a global shortfall of nine million nurses, with some of the worst affected countries located in Asia.[[footnote 3]] While investments in hospitals and physician health infrastructure will continue to rise, traditional, labor-intensive care delivery models are unlikely to meet Asia\u0026rsquo;s rising health needs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRising consumer expectations:\u003c/em\u003e Consumers are spending more on health and wellness and increasingly demand access to convenient, affordable care. Furthermore, our consumer research has indicated that consumers are trading up in health and safety, with consumers in China, for example, willing to spend more on health-branded products during the pandemic. According to \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/feeling-good-the-future-of-the-1-5-trillion-wellness-market\"\u003eMcKinsey research\u003c/a\u003e, 43.5 percent of Chinese consumers are reportedly spending more on their health in the past 12 months and 23.1 percent are spending more on their nutrition.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGrowing financial burden:\u003c/em\u003e Today, governments in Asia, on average, spend only 4.5 percent of GDP on healthcare, compared with the OECD average of 12 percent. Yet governments are the dominant payer in Asia, accounting for 64 percent of all health expenditures in 2018 (compared with private insurers, which covered 7 percent). Finding ways to control the growth of healthcare expenditures remains an urgent public priority even while prioritizing quality and access for patients.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTechnological innovation:\u003c/em\u003e Asia is home to half the world\u0026rsquo;s internet users, and already leads digital innovation worldwide in multiple sectors.[[footnote 4]] Indeed, venture capital and private equity investments in digital health in Asia have grown at 38 percent CAGR from 2015 to 2020. As a result, as of 2020, Asia comprises 44 percent of global venture capital/private equity investments in digital health\u0026mdash;$6 billion of $14 billion.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\u003ch2\u003eThe rise of health ecosystems in Asia\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsumer-centric digital ecosystems are emerging across the world in response to these fundamental forces disrupting healthcare.[[footnote 5]] Such ecosystems are designed to seamlessly deliver the right care in the right setting at the right time by integrating three critical components: (a) a network of health-service providers across care settings, (b) a system of intelligence that leverages behavioral, social, and health data to analyze patients\u0026rsquo; needs and selects the appropriate provider, and (c) a technology backbone that enables data and insights to flow between care providers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eImportantly, health ecosystems are \u003cem\u003eenabled\u003c/em\u003e by digital but are not \u003cem\u003epurely\u003c/em\u003e digital, as they integrate both digital and physical health services. In addition, the breadth and complexity of health ecosystems means they cannot be encapsulated by a single entity, but typically consist of a central orchestrator anchored around a few self-built business models. They also manage multiple partners, including brick-and-mortar providers, healthtech start-ups, and IT vendors, to cover a more complete part of the care continuum.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs we discussed in \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-healthcare-innovation-the-evolution-of-ecosystems\"\u003eThe next wave of healthcare innovation: The evolution of ecosystems\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;healthcare ecosystems of the future will likely be defined by the needs of different patient populations and their associated effective care journeys (including beyond care itself). The consumer-oriented nature of these ecosystems also will increase the number of healthcare touchpoints, with the goal of modifying patient behavior and improving outcomes.\u0026rdquo; Across Asia, a wide spectrum of players are beginning to define their approach to health ecosystems\u0026mdash;not only healthcare incumbents such as insurers, providers, and governments but also nontraditional entrants such as consumer-technology giants, banks, telco-companies, industrial and retail conglomerates, and others. Emerging health ecosystems already impact more than a billion lives across Asia today (Exhibit 2), with prominent examples emerging in China, India, and Indonesia, among other markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eFour archetypes of health ecosystems are now emerging with different anchor use cases:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBroadening access to primary care:\u003c/em\u003e Many of the largest health ecosystem players in Asia have rapidly grown by combining telemedicine and e-pharmacy services to address underserved populations. In China, for example, Ping An Good Doctor\u0026rsquo;s initial value proposition was allowing users to see a doctor online in minutes rather than waiting in line at a hospital for hours. Patients who required an in-person follow-up could subsequently get an expedited appointment booking at a hospital. Ping An Good Doctor then expanded into e-commerce transactions, providing consumer health products, generics, and health checkup kits on its platform.\u003cbr /\u003e\n    \u003cbr /\u003e\n    By contrast, AliHealth began with an e-pharmacy proposition in 2011, managing drug sales on Alibaba\u0026rsquo;s Tmall e-commerce platform and then expanding to home delivery of medications, provider partnerships for teleconsultations, appointment booking, and e-payments. Likewise in India, Practo launched as one of the first platforms to connect hospital-based physicians to patients across the country via video- and phone-based consultations, then expanded into medicine delivery, electronic health records management for hospitals, and even medical insurance services. Finally, in Indonesia, Halodoc has emerged as one of the largest platforms for patients to easily access general practitioner teleconsults, pharmacy delivery, and home lab services across more than 50 cities, addressing the lack of easy access to primary care outside of major hubs such as Jakarta and Surabaya.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImproving health and wellness:\u003c/em\u003e Some public and private payers have begun leveraging digital technologies to nudge consumers to monitor their health and lower the long-term cost of care. For example, since 2015 the Health Promotion Board (HPB) of Singapore has run the Healthy 365 program, which gamifies wellness by awarding redeemable Healthpoints based on daily step counts, healthy food purchases, health screenings, and more.[[footnote 6]] In 2020, HPB expanded its program by partnering with Apple to launch LumiHealth, which layers in additional activity and wellness challenges for users of the Apple Watch.[[footnote 7]] Similarly, private payers such as AIA and Prudential have launched personalized wellness programs (AIA Vitality[[footnote 8]] and Pulse by Prudential,[[footnote 9]] respectively) to actively engage policyholders and guide them to the appropriate health provider.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eExpediting access to acute care:\u003c/em\u003e An increasing number of hospitals are looking to establish digital \u0026ldquo;front doors\u0026rdquo; to engage with patients before and after their visit. Singapore has taken this model across its public healthcare system, with its HealthHub application serving as a single comprehensive digital entry point for all citizens to book appointments, order medications, and access vaccination records, disease risk assessments, and other health content. In addition, this model has scaled intensively in China, with close to 1,000 such \u0026ldquo;internet hospitals\u0026rdquo; established by early 2021 and detailed guidelines on social insurance reimbursement of online activities published by more than 20 cities. Approximately 70 percent of the internet hospitals are established by brick-and-mortar hospitals, such as Peking Union Medical College (PUMC) Hospital in Beijing and Huashan Hospital in Shanghai, and the remainder are led by digital consumer giants, such as Alibaba, Tencent, and Ping An.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eManaging and monitoring disease:\u003c/em\u003e Following the success of Livongo and Omada in the United States, interest in digital chronic disease management platforms has increased across Asia. Among the largest examples are Medlinker and ClouDr in China, both of which have focused on building platforms to connect patients, physicians, payers, providers, and pharmacies. In fact, Medlinker has collaborated with 50,000 physicians and built patient-management tools to address diabetes, hepatic disease, and kidney disease.[[footnote 10]] Medlinker also offers e-pharmacy services in collaboration with pharmaceutical companies. Meanwhile, ClouDr has taken a slightly different approach, establishing closer ties to hospitals by building a software-as-a-service platform for disease management[[footnote 11]] and providing prescriptions to patients who can collect drugs at offline pharmacy chains.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo date, the markets have rewarded emerging health ecosystem innovators. As of March 2021, Tencent\u0026rsquo;s WeDoctor is estimated to be valued at up to $6.8 billion, which is 24 times the price-to-revenue ratio,[[footnote 12]] well in line with Ping An Good Doctor\u0026rsquo;s ratio of 16 times price-to-revenue, and significantly above the average price-to-revenue ratio of brick-and-mortar health providers in Asia, which is around tenfold. Even companies with smaller but rapidly scaling health ecosystems have seen valuation boosts supported in part by health ecosystem approaches. For example, Apollo Hospitals, one of the largest hospitals in India, launched its Apollo 24/7 health ecosystem in February 2020 to provide teleconsultations and home delivery of medicines. It announced strong results for the second half of FY 2021 in June.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the other hand, there are lessons that orchestrators need to draw to capture opportunities from the promising fundamentals and trends. First, building a successful ecosystem relies on aligning interests and connecting multiple stakeholders (for example, government, payer, provider, physician, and patients) within health systems, and in-depth analysis about the pain points of each party (down to the operational level) is key to reveal the opportunities. Second, a digital ecosystem does not imply a pure online approach and a successful model would require integration of both online and offline resources to build the care continuum and achieve the best outcomes. Third, the design of each business model will require definition of at least three functions, that is, flow generation, transaction conversion, and profit creation, to ensure a sustainable development.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003ch2\u003eKey questions to ask when building digital health ecosystems\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the impressive impact numbers achieved to date by several health ecosystem players, we believe significant opportunity remains to expand the scope and breadth of health ecosystems across Asia. Speed is critical to capturing value in this nascent market, as the winner-take-all dynamics of ecosystem-based markets heavily favor first movers or fast followers. Thus, potential health ecosystem orchestrators should ask themselves the following four key questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhat is the source of advantage?\u003c/em\u003e Successful ecosystem players typically start with a control point in mind. Consumer technology giants, such as Tencent with WeChat or Alibaba with Tmall, leverage their existing consumer platforms as an entry point upon which to offer health-related services. Payers, such as Ping An, AIA, and Prudential, leverage their large-scale distribution networks and access to patients\u0026rsquo; claims data to shape service offerings. Finally, providers, such as Apollo, leverage their access to physicians and trusted reputation in health.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhat strategic capabilities and partnerships should be developed?\u003c/em\u003e Being able to rapidly strike partnerships is a critical strategic muscle for ecosystem orchestrators expand services beyond their initial capabilities. For example, Halodoc partners with GoJek to leverage GoJek\u0026rsquo;s broad transportation network for home delivery of medications across Indonesia\u0026mdash;a service that would be cost-prohibitive for the company to develop on its own. Tencent partners with pharma or medtech companies to develop AI-based diagnostics, or invests directly in healthtech start-ups.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhat is the time horizon and risk appetite to invest?\u003c/em\u003e Given the complexity of healthcare, health ecosystems require significant investment over a long time horizon to successfully create their partnership network and user base. Ping An Good Doctor, for example, grew revenues by 35.5 percent from 2019 to 2020 but still recorded an adjusted net loss in 2020 of $80 million, six years after founding. Ping An, however, notes that 15 percent to 20 percent of new financial customers for their main businesses are sourced from their healthcare ecosystem each year.[[footnote 14]] Indeed, rather than seeking to turn an immediate profit, companies seeking to develop health ecosystems should look at growth metrics or core business synergies as leading indicators of platform success.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHow will stakeholders interface with government healthcare priorities and regulators?\u003c/em\u003e COVID-19 has led some local health governments to pilot online care delivery and virtual health, while still evaluating any fallout related to compliance, data security, and privacy. Working closely with local governments to develop digital health solutions could accelerate adoption and value capture.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe that digital health ecosystems represent the future of healthcare in Asia and beyond. Both healthcare incumbents and new entrants will need to define what their future roles will be in orchestrating or participating in health ecosystems. Answering these four questions can help ecosystem orchestrators assess how they will realize the value at stake associated with building a digital health ecosystem, and thereby impact patients\u0026rsquo; lives across
